senses.sense_definition: An Athenian system of education designed to give students a broad cultural background focusing on integration into the public life of the city-state with subject matter including gymnastics, grammar, rhetoric, music, mathematics, geography, natural history, and philosophy.

examples.text: Historians study <w>paideia</w> to understand how ancient Athens cultivated active and capable citizens.
The curriculum of classical <w>paideia</w> required young men to master both physical sports and intellectual rhetoric.

senses.sense_definition: The epitome of physical and intellectual achievement to which an Ancient Greek citizen could aspire; societal and cultural perfection.

examples.text: He strove for <w>paideia</w>, seeking a perfect balance between a healthy body and a sharp mind.
This sculpture embodies the ideal of <w>paideia</w> that was highly valued by that civilization.

senses.sense_definition: An early model of Christian higher learning having theology as its chief subject.

examples.text: The monastery preserved a form of Christian <w>paideia</w> throughout the turbulent Middle Ages.
Scholars debate how much classical thought influenced this religious <w>paideia</w> focused on scripture.

senses.sense_definition: A pedagogical system focusing on providing children with a broad and balanced education.

examples.text: Modern educators sometimes refer to <w>paideia</w> when discussing holistic learning methods for children.
The proposal suggests a return to <w>paideia</w> to foster well-rounded students rather than specialists.
